profileText: A Representative from Delaware; born near Wilmington, Del., in 1776; was graduated from Princeton College in 1794; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1801 and practiced in New Castle and Wilmington, Del., and Baltimore, Md.; elected as a Federalist to the Ninth and Tenth Congresses and served from March 4, 1805, until his resignation in 1807, before the assembling of the Tenth Congress; moved to Philadelphia, Pa., in 1819 and resumed the practice of law; member of the Pennsylvania house of representatives in 1824; died in Philadelphia, Pa., January 15, 1850; interment in St. Mary's Churchyard, Hamilton Village (now a part of Philadelphia), Pa.

researchRecord.name: 1839, 1 item (2 pages).
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Broom to John F. Watson, dated December 3, 1839, encouraging John Watson in his project of silkworm cultivation. James Broom sent John Watson's letter to a friend to further explore possibilities.

researchRecord.name: 1820, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Broom to the Philadelphia Society for Promoting Agriculture.
